React Native Architecture — Old Vs New







Sugand singh



·Follow




3 min read·
Aug 24, 2023








--










Listen









Share












Introduction
In the world of mobile app development, React Native has emerged as a game-changer, allowing developers to build cross-platform applications efficiently. Over the years, the architecture of React Native has evolved, transitioning from its early days to a more refined and powerful structure. In this article, we’ll explore the journey of React Native architecture, comparing the old and new approaches and highlighting the benefits of the newer architecture.
The Old Architecture
In its early stages, React Native relied on a bridge-based architecture to connect JavaScript code with native modules. This architecture, while innovative at the time, came with certain limitations that impacted performance and development speed. Here are some characteristics of the old architecture:
Bridge Communication: React Native’s old architecture used a bridge to communicate between JavaScript and native modules, causing a performance bottleneck. Frequent communication between the two sides could lead to latency issues, making the app feel less responsive.
Limited Native Controls: Access to native UI components was restricted, often requiring developers to write custom native modules for complex UI elements. This hindered the ability to provide a truly native experience
Thread Management: Handling threads for UI and JavaScript separately was complex, leading to synchronization issues and occasional app crashes.
Debugging Challenges: Debugging native modules and JavaScript code simultaneously was challenging due to the disconnected nature of the architecture.
Development Efficiency: While React Native aimed to provide a faster development cycle, the old architecture sometimes hampered this goal due to performance bottlenecks and limitations.


RN-Old ArchitectureThe New Architecture
React Native’s architecture has evolved significantly to address the limitations of the old approach. With contributions from the community and advancements in the ecosystem, the new architecture focuses on enhancing performance, stability, and development efficiency. Here are the key improvements in the new architecture:
TurboModules: TurboModules replace the old bridge communication system, significantly improving performance by enabling direct communication between JavaScript and native modules. This reduces latency and enhances overall app responsiveness.
Fabric: The new architecture introduces React Native Fabric, a reimagined UI framework that allows for asynchronous rendering of components. This enhances the app’s performance by efficiently managing the UI thread.
Native Module Enhancement: The new architecture provides better support for native modules, allowing developers to easily integrate native functionality and UI components into their apps.
Multithreading: React Native’s new architecture employs multithreading to separate UI rendering from JavaScript execution, resulting in improved thread management and fewer app crashes.
Hermes JavaScript Engine: The new architecture encourages the use of the Hermes JavaScript engine, which optimizes startup time, memory usage, and JavaScript execution speed.


RN-New ArchitectureBenefits of the New Architecture
The shift from the old to the new architecture in React Native brings several benefits to developers and end-users alike:
Improved Performance: With direct communication between JavaScript and native modules, reduced latency, and enhanced UI rendering, the new architecture results in a smoother and more responsive app experience.
Enhanced Native Feel: The new architecture’s support for native modules and components allows developers to create apps that feel more native and offer a consistent user experience across platforms.
Easier Debugging: The new architecture simplifies debugging by providing better tools and more streamlined processes for identifying and fixing issues in both JavaScript and native code.
Faster Development: Thanks to the performance improvements and efficient thread management, developers can iterate faster and bring new features to market more quickly.
Conclusion
React Native’s journey from its old architecture to the new one showcases the commitment of the development community to refining and enhancing the framework. The new architecture’s focus on performance, stability, and native integration has paved the way for a brighter future for React Native app development. As a developer, embracing the new architecture empowers you to create high-quality cross-platform apps that deliver exceptional user experiences.

</figure><h1 id="4d4c" class="mx my gt be mz na nb nc nd ne nf ng nh ni nj nk nl nm nn no np nq nr ns nt nu bj">Introduction</h1>
<p id="6895" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq or os gm bj">In the world of mobile app development, React Native has emerged as a game-changer, allowing developers to build cross-platform applications efficiently. Over the years, the architecture of React Native has evolved, transitioning from its early days to a more refined and powerful structure. In this article, we’ll explore the journey of React Native architecture, comparing the old and new approaches and highlighting the benefits of the newer architecture.</p>
<h1 id="610c" class="mx my gt be mz na nb nc nd ne nf ng nh ni nj nk nl nm nn no np nq nr ns nt nu bj">The Old Architecture</h1>
<p id="e6cc" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq or os gm bj">In its early stages, React Native relied on a bridge-based architecture to connect JavaScript code with native modules. This architecture, while innovative at the time, came with certain limitations that impacted performance and development speed. Here are some characteristics of the old architecture:</p>
<p id="3b67" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Bridge Communication</strong>: React Native’s old architecture used a bridge to communicate between JavaScript and native modules, causing a performance bottleneck. Frequent communication between the two sides could lead to latency issues, making the app feel less responsive.</p>
<p id="29f3" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Limited Native Controls:</strong> Access to native UI components was restricted, often requiring developers to write custom native modules for complex UI elements. This hindered the ability to provide a truly native experience</p>
<p id="4c8a" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Thread Management: </strong>Handling threads for UI and JavaScript separately was complex, leading to synchronization issues and occasional app crashes.</p>
<p id="f903" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Debugging Challenges: </strong>Debugging native modules and JavaScript code simultaneously was challenging due to the disconnected nature of the architecture.</p>
<p id="c2a4" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Development Efficiency:</strong> While React Native aimed to provide a faster development cycle, the old architecture sometimes hampered this goal due to performance bottlenecks and limitations.</p>

<figcaption class="pd fe pe mj mk pf pg be b bf z dt">RN-Old Architecture</figcaption></figure><h1 id="c6c3" class="mx my gt be mz na nb nc nd ne nf ng nh ni nj nk nl nm nn no np nq nr ns nt nu bj">The New Architecture</h1>
<p id="a504" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq or os gm bj">React Native’s architecture has evolved significantly to address the limitations of the old approach. With contributions from the community and advancements in the ecosystem, the new architecture focuses on enhancing performance, stability, and development efficiency. Here are the key improvements in the new architecture:</p>
<p id="8ea7" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">TurboModules:</strong> TurboModules replace the old bridge communication system, significantly improving performance by enabling direct communication between JavaScript and native modules. This reduces latency and enhances overall app responsiveness.</p>
<p id="9983" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Fabric:</strong> The new architecture introduces React Native Fabric, a reimagined UI framework that allows for asynchronous rendering of components. This enhances the app’s performance by efficiently managing the UI thread.</p>
<p id="a598" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Native Module Enhancement: </strong>The new architecture provides better support for native modules, allowing developers to easily integrate native functionality and UI components into their apps.</p>
<p id="1da6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Multithreading: </strong>React Native’s new architecture employs multithreading to separate UI rendering from JavaScript execution, resulting in improved thread management and fewer app crashes.</p>
<p id="4880" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Hermes JavaScript Engine: </strong>The new architecture encourages the use of the Hermes JavaScript engine, which optimizes startup time, memory usage, and JavaScript execution speed.</p>
<figure class="oy oz pa pb pc mr mj mk paragraph-image"><div role="button" tabindex="0" class="ms mt fi mu bg mv"><div class="mj mk ml"><picture><source <figcaption class="pd fe pe mj mk pf pg be b bf z dt">RN-New Architecture</figcaption></figure><h1 id="f094" class="mx my gt be mz na nb nc nd ne nf ng nh ni nj nk nl nm nn no np nq nr ns nt nu bj">Benefits of the New Architecture</h1>
<p id="7369" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq or os gm bj">The shift from the old to the new architecture in React Native brings several benefits to developers and end-users alike:</p>
<p id="0aad" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Improved Performance: </strong>With direct communication between JavaScript and native modules, reduced latency, and enhanced UI rendering, the new architecture results in a smoother and more responsive app experience.</p>
<p id="46ff" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Enhanced Native Feel:</strong> The new architecture’s support for native modules and components allows developers to create apps that feel more native and offer a consistent user experience across platforms.</p>
<p id="3854" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Easier Debugging: </strong>The new architecture simplifies debugging by providing better tools and more streamlined processes for identifying and fixing issues in both JavaScript and native code.</p>
<p id="006b" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny ot oa ob oc ou oe of og ov oi oj ok ow om on oo ox oq or os gm bj"><strong class="nx gu">Faster Development: </strong>Thanks to the performance improvements and efficient thread management, developers can iterate faster and bring new features to market more quickly.</p>
<h1 id="00a7" class="mx my gt be mz na nb nc nd ne nf ng nh ni nj nk nl nm nn no np nq nr ns nt nu bj"><strong class="al">Conclusion</strong></h1>
<p id="2969" class="pw-post-body-paragraph nv nw gt nx b ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol om on oo op oq or os gm bj">React Native’s journey from its old architecture to the new one showcases the commitment of the development community to refining and enhancing the framework. The new architecture’s focus on performance, stability, and native integration has paved the way for a brighter future for React Native app development. As a developer, embracing the new architecture empowers you to create high-quality cross-platform apps that deliver exceptional user experiences.</p>
